{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3488216,"name":"Tom Corrigan","username":"tcorrigan5878","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/779978/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-20T18:07:37.317Z","cooked":"

We’re trying to do swerve driving using Rev Robotics Spark MAX Controllers. All the example code I’ve seen creates the controller objects like this:

self.drivingSparkMax = rev.CANSparkMax(driveMotorChannel, rev.CANSparkMax.MotorType.kBrushless)`

Problem is that the name CANSparkMax cannot be imported from ‘rev’. This happens whether using import rev or from rev import CANSparkMax at the start of the module. Have definitely installed the latest version of the rev module.

Migrating to REVLib 2025 | REV ION Brushless

This explains my problem. But how to convert our existing python code to use the new library is not clear. It would help if Rev Robotics would provide the python equivalent of their C++/Java examples.

Do you have any specific questions about migrating the rev code? We migrated to Python last year and dealt with some of the rev issues you have probably run into this season. Feel free to ask me anything specific you have about that. Your code should work if you change CANSparkMax to just SparkMax.

It actually doesn’t. Without good examples to follow I find this kind of documentation useless.

There’s more too it then just changing CANSparkMax to SparkMax. The mechanism for changing the configuration of the controllers has changed significantly. We, too, just started using Python last year but do not have a lot of expertise with it. Using swerve drives this year is new to us. We were planning on using the edubu MAX-Swerve-Template but that code no longer works with the new Rev controller library. Because we need to get things up and running NOW we’re switching back to Java and using Rev’s Java template.

Some of the RobotPy rev examples are fixed in Add testing for examples by sciencewhiz · Pull Request #74 · robotpy/robotpy-rev · GitHub… but apparently not all of them. Rev has a lot more examples that need to be ported to Python too (Port REV's examples · Issue #9 · robotpy/robotpy-rev · GitHub)

On macOS it also crashes, there’s an error related to the sim devices in physics.py. If you rename physics.py to anything else (which disables physics) then the error goes away.

The access violation appears to either be a RobotPy or WPILib bug, but I won’t be able to dig into it until this evening. Filed bug here for now: [BUG]: crash in simdevice · Issue #144 · robotpy/mostrobotpy · GitHub

2881 fully migrated to Python over the off-season and put together a base swerve drive project for the team members. A git submodule approach is used across our projects where the swerve module component is shared among other things, but how the new REV config patterns are handled inline with constants classes may be a helpful pattern to check out. We definitely did not approach this base project as a template/framework for other teams as compared to making it efficient for our internal teams first and foremost, so YMMV. (We do not have simulation with REV support integrated yet … that is a WIP for us, but we have PathPlanner, PhotonVision, et al working across all our projects).

frc2881/Robot-Base-Swerve: Source code for a base swerve drive robot

frc2881/Robot-Lib: Library submodule with common code shared between base robot projects

It is a RobotPy bug, fixed in SimDevice: only release GIL when calling API by virtuald · Pull Request #145 · robotpy/mostrobotpy · GitHub … probably will do a 2025.2.1.1 release either later tonight or tomorrow morning, depending on CI.
